task:
Task:
  The response compares two or more subjects, highlighting relationships such as similarities, differences, or tradeoffs.
constraints: Completeness ("skim"): The response performs only a very light pass, addressing the most obvious or critical issues without aiming for completeness.
Scope ("good"): The response focuses on how quality, success, or goodness is judged—criteria, metrics, standards, values, or taste—assuming a framing rather than defining it or shifting perspective.
Method ("dimension"): The response enhances the task by exploring multiple dimensions or axes of analysis, making implicit factors explicit and examining how they interact.
Form ("activities"): The response organizes ideas as concrete session activities or segments—what to do, by whom, and in what order—rather than abstract description.

Channel ("adr"): The response takes the shape of an Architecture Decision Record (ADR) document with sections for context, decision, and consequences, formatted as a structured document ready for version control.
Directional ("jog"): The response modifies the task to interpret the intent and carry it out directly without asking follow-up questions.
